articles.title: Nvidia’s Made-in-the-U.S.A. Move Follows a Familiar Trump Pattern
articles.content: Chip maker  Nvidia  unveiled plans Monday to produce new made-in-America supercomputers that power artificial intelligence, just one day after the Trump administration said tariffs were coming for semiconductor-reliant imports.  The chip maker said it would make AI supercomputers with contract manufacturers in Texas, its first public disclosure of a plan that would amplify ongoing U.S. efforts to bring semiconductor production back to domestic markets.  A darling of the global AI boom, Nvidia promised an eye-popping $500 billion in spending in the coming years, an announcement that echoed a similar goal disclosed by  Apple  in February.

articles.title: Apple and other tech stocks rebound after Trump offers more tariffs guidance
articles.content: Apple, Nvidia and other tech company stocks rebounded on Monday, after the Trump administration said tariffs affecting the electronics industry on products like smartphones are coming later.

articles.title: VIX, Wall Street’s fear gauge, sinks nearly 20% on temporary tech tariff relief
articles.content: Investing.com -- The VIX, or fear index, collapsed 18% on Monday to $30.73. It has been as high as $65.73 in the recent tariff melee.

articles.title: Why Apple (AAPL) Stock Is Up Today
articles.content: Shares of iPhone and iPad maker Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) jumped 2.2% in the morning session after reports indicated that smartphones, computers, and a wide range of tech devices and components would be exempt from the reciprocal tariffs on U.S. imports announced on April 2, 2025. The list of spared goods includes chips, solar panels, flat-screen TVs, flash drives, and memory cards.

articles.title: Apple fans won’t stay loyal if tariffs mean $2,000 iPhones, top analyst warns
articles.content: Tariff uncertainty will cause chaos in the supply chain, says Wedbush’s Dan Ives.

articles.title: Apple Stock Gets an Upgrade From KeyBanc on Tech Tariff Exemptions
articles.content: Apple stock was upgraded by KeyBanc after smartphones, computers, and other electronics were exempted from President Donald Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs.

articles.title: Trump Tariff Confusion Whipsaws Tech
articles.content: IDC's Ryan Reith joins to discuss the latest tariff confusion and impact on tech manufacturers, saying he's skeptical of a quick shift to manufacturing in the US. He joins Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology".
